STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
February 29, 2024
Darnell Thomas Britt
COMMUNITY CARE ORGANIZATION
18688 JOANN ST,
DETROIT, MI, 48205-2748
Re: License #: CB820315857
SI #: 2024C0001069SI
Dear Darnell Thomas Britt:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2024C0001069SI
Special Investigation Intake Date: January 18, 2024
License #: CB820315857
Licensee Group Organization: Community Care Organization
Licensee Designee: Kendra Washington
Chief Administrator: Darnell Thomas Britt
Agency Name: COMMUNITY CARE ORGANIZATION
Agency Address: 18688 JOANN ST
DETROIT, MI 48205-2748
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 01/28/2026
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
1/19/2024 8:15 AM Other
1/19/2024 8:15 AM Email Special Investigation Initiation
1/19/2024 2:02 PM Other
1/22/2024 8:00 AM Other
1/24/2024 10:44 AM Other
1/25/2024 12:31 PM Video Conference Special Investigation Initiation
1/25/2024 12:33 PM Video Conference Special Investigation Initiation
1/26/2024 12:34 PM Video Conference Special Investigation Initiation
2/1/2024 12:36 PM Email Other
2/1/2024 12:37 PM Email Other
III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code Staff responsibilities
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207
Section • (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be
Description directly responsible for all the following activities:
• (a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home
care. Social service workers shall work directly with
the children, their families, and other relevant
individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service
plans for the children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The IL Plus program accepted case management and then
refused to work with the parent. Failed to ensure the child had
access to food, failed to document IL skills, failed to gain state ID.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant/Foster Care Supervisor 1 – Complainant, who is
also Foster Care Supervisor 1, was interviewed via Microsoft
Teams on 1/25/2024. She indicated she has been assigned as the
foster care supervisor at Lenawee County DHHS for Youth A’s
case since he came into care. Foster Care Supervisor 1 reported
Youth A was referred to Community Care Organization’s
Independent Living Plus (ILP) home and program by Lenawee
County DHHS staff upon removal from his parental home.
Community Care Organization staff were made aware that Youth
A had a goal of reunification and were informed they would be
expected to work with Youth A’s birth parent during the referral
process and accepted the case. Foster Care Supervisor 1
reported this is documented in email communications. After
accepting Youth A’s case, Community Care Organization’s
Program Manager (Foster Care Supervisor 2) told Foster Care
Supervisor 1 that Community Care Organization does not provide
services to birth parents. Foster Care Supervisor 1 reported she
reviewed Community Care Organization’s contract and realized
they do not provide service to birth parents at which time Lenawee
County DHHS took over case management of Youth A. Foster
Care Supervisor 1 stated she was assigned as primary supervisor
and a DHHS foster care worker was signed as the primary worker
on the case as of 7/24/2023. During this interview, Foster Care
Supervisor 1 expressed her misunderstanding of the Independent
2

Living Plus contract. She came to the realization that Community
Care Organization staff were not responsible for the allegations
she included in her complaint against them as they were no longer
responsible for case management of Youth A once she told them
the local office would be taking over case management
responsibility of Youth A.
Foster Care Worker 1 – Foster Care Worker 1 was interviewed
via Microsoft Teams on 1/25/2024. She reported she was not the
initial DHHS foster care worker assigned but was assigned to
Youth A’s case as primary foster care worker in August of 2023.
She reported she believed Community Care Organization staff
were responsible for providing food for youths who did not have
their own and for obtaining Youth A’s state identification. She also
reported she never received documentation of independent living
skills education provided by Community Care Organization staff
despite having asked. During her interview, she did not fully
understand the Independent Living Plus contract and, despite
being assigned as primary foster care worker in August of 2023,
she had the expectation Community Care Organization staff would
be providing the foster care and independent living case
management.
Foster Care Supervisor 2 – Foster Care Supervisor 2, who is
also the Program Manager for Community Care Organization, was
interviewed via Microsoft Teams on 1/26/2024. She reported she
accepted Youth A into Community Care Organization under the
terms of their contract. She stated her understanding at the time
the case was accepted was that Lenawee County DHHS would
have family responsibility of the case to work with Youth A’s
sibling and parents and Community Care Organization would have
case management of Youth A only, which is what has historically
happened whenever they accept a case involving parents and
siblings. Foster Care Supervisor 2 stated she was initially
assigned as the supervisor for the whole case and had multiple
conversations and email exchanges with Foster Care Supervisor 1
to explain that she had only accepted case management
responsibilities on Youth A and that her agency could not provide
case management to the younger sibling and parents as their
contract does not allow them to do so. Foster Care Supervisor 2
stated it did not seem as if Foster Care Supervisor 1 understood
what Foster Care Supervisor 2 was attempting to explain and on
7/24/2023 Lenawee County DHHS staff assigned themselves as
primary workers and supervisor on Youth A’s case resulting in
Foster Care Supervisor 2 and her staff no longer having the ability
to perform any primary functions within the electronic case record.
3

She stated she did ask Foster Care Supervisor 1 to add Foster
Care Supervisor 2 back as primary supervisor on Youth A’s case
multiple times, but this never occurred. She indicated her agency
continues to provide case management services as best they
could, but they had limitations due to not being assigned case
management responsibilities. She reported they did continue to
provide independent living skills training to Youth A, which they
have documented in their internal case record. She stated she
would ask someone at the agency to pull the closed record and
provide that documentation for review.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
Placement history in Youth A’s electronic case record:
• 6/16/2023 – 10/20/2023 Community Care Organization
Case assignments in Youth A’s electronic case record:
• Primary Supervisor
6/16/2023 – 7/24/2023, Supervisor 2 (Community Care
Organization)
7/24/2023 – 10/20/2023, Foster Care Supervisor 1
(Lenawee DHHS)
• Secondary Supervisor
6/16/2023 – 7/24/2023, Foster Care Supervisor 1 (Lenawee
DHHS)
7/24/2023 – 10/20/2023, Supervisor 2 (Community Care
Organization)
• Primary Worker
6/16/2023 – 7/10/2023, Foster Care Worker 3 (Community
Care Organization)
7/10/2023-7/24/2023, Foster Care Worker 2 (Community
Care Organization)
7/24/2023 - 8/16/2023, Foster Care Worker 4 (Lenawee
DHHS)
8/16/2023 – 10/20/2024, Foster Care Worker 1 (Lenawee
DHHS)
• Secondary Worker
6/16/2023 – 7/24/2023, Foster Care Worker 4 (Lenawee
DHHS)
6/21/2023 – 10/20/2023, Foster Care Worker 2 (Community
Care Organization)
Case Referral and Acceptance form (DHS-3600) effective date
6/16/2023 signed by Program Manager 1 on 6/21/2023 and
4

Community Care Organization’s Director on 6/22/2023 indicating
the contract is for ILP services.
Emails between Community Care Organization and Lenawee
DHHS staff provided by Foster Care Supervisor 1:
• 6/15/2023 to DHHS accepting Youth A into Community
Care Organization’s program.
• 6/16/2023 from DHHS asking if Community Care
Organization handles the foster care portion.
• 6/20/2023 from Foster Care Worker 2 with the information
needed by Foster Care Worker 4 to enter in 3600.
• 6/21/2023 from Foster Care Worker 4 to Foster Care
Supervisor 2 indicating the 3600 is attached and asking if
Foster Care Worker 2 should be assigned in MiSACWIS.
• 7/14/2023 from Foster Care Worker 4 to Foster Care
Worker 2 and Foster Care Supervisor 2 stating she is
meeting with the birth mother and asking if either Foster
Care Worker 2 or Supervisor 2 would like to attend that
meeting.
• 7/14/2023 from Foster Care Supervisor 2 to Foster Care
Worker 4 stating she could meet with the mother during
that meeting. She also indicated she was informed DHHS
should have “full family” as Community Care Organization
only has one of the youths.
• 7/18/2023 from Foster Care Supervisor 1 to Foster Care
Supervisor 2 asking what is meant by Foster Care
Supervisor 2’s email stating MDHHS should have full
family.
• 7/18/2023 from Foster Care Supervisor 2 to Foster Care
Supervisor 1 stating Community Care Organization only
has responsibility for Youth A per their contract.
• 7/24/2023 Email from Foster Care Supervisor 1 to Foster
Care Supervisor 2 stating she read through the ILP contract
and that as soon as the ISP is approved, DHHS would take
back case management of Youth A with an apology for the
confusion.
• 7/25/2023 from Foster Care Worker 1 to Foster Care
Worker 2 asking her to unassign herself so Foster Care
Worker 4 could be assigned.
• 8/2/2023 from Foster Care Supervisor 2 to Foster Care
Supervisor 1 asking to be assigned to the case.
• 8/2/2023 from Foster Care Supervisor 1 asking Foster Care
Supervisor 2 what she would like to be assigned as in the
case record.
• 8/2/2023 from Foster Care Supervisor 2 to Foster Care
Supervisor 1 stating she is the foster care supervisor.
5

• 8/3/2023 from Foster Care Supervisor 2 to Foster Care
Worker 4 requesting the case be assigned to Community
Care Organization as they could not do any work on the
case.
• 8/3/2023 from Foster Care Worker 4 to Foster Care
Supervisor 2 stating she would talk with her supervisor.
• 8/3/2023 from Foster Care Supervisor 2 asking what role
Foster Care Supervisor 2 would be assigned as in the case
record since DHHS took over foster care responsibility.
• 8/4/2023 from Foster Care Supervisor 2 to Foster Care
Supervisor 1 indicating she requested the case be
assigned back as they cannot complete any work.
• 8/4/2023 from Foster Care Supervisor 1 stating she
assigned Foster Care Supervisor 2 as secondary
supervisor so she can enter data and asking what data she
would need to enter now that she is not in the foster care
role.
• 8/7/2023 Foster Care Supervisor 2 to Foster Care
Supervisor 1 with a screenshot example of another case in
which a different agency has full family responsibility while
Community Care Organization has responsibility of one
youth with a request to discuss by phone.
Analysis Violation is not established as Community Care Organization had
agreed to provide ILP services to Youth A as of 6/16/2023, which
does not include reunification services to Youth A’s parent.
Community Care Organization was responsible for foster care and
independent living services to Youth A during that time; however,
DHHS staff took back case management responsibilities of Youth
A on 7/24/2023. Therefore, Community Care Organization was not
responsible for case management of Youth A after 7/24/2023.
Additionally, Community Care Organization is not responsible for
obtaining a youth’s identification or providing food for youths in
their program.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Development of service plans
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12418
Section • (2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
Description child and parent or parents, as follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal
and at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
6

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency failed to submit reports timely.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant/Foster Care Supervisor 1 – Complainant, who is
also Foster Care Supervisor 1, was interviewed via Microsoft
Teams on 1/25/2024. Foster Care Worker 1 reported Foster Care
Worker 2 did not complete the initial service plan timely.
Foster Care Supervisor 2 – Foster Care Supervisor 2, who is
also the Program Manager for Community Care Organization, was
interviewed via Microsoft Teams on 1/26/2024. She reported the
initial service plan was not completed timely due to the MiSACWIS
assignments being incorrect.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
Case assignments in Youth A’s electronic case record:
• Primary Supervisor
6/16/2023 – 7/24/2023, Supervisor 2 (Community Care
Organization)
• Primary Worker
6/16/2023 – 7/10/2023, Foster Care Worker 3 (Community
Care Organization)
7/10/2023-7/24/2023, Foster Care Worker 2 (Community
Care Organization)
Initial Service Plan due 7/15/2023 completed by Foster Care
Worker 2 on 7/20/2023.
Analysis Violation is established due to the Initial service plan being
completed 5 days late.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Visitation and family time; in person contact
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421
Section • (2) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster
Description child, and the foster parent, if applicable, in the child's
placement at least once every month.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency failed to complete social work contact timely.
7

Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant/Foster Care Supervisor 1 – Complainant, who is
also Foster Care Supervisor 1, was interviewed via Microsoft
Teams on 1/25/2024. Foster Care Worker 1 stated she realizes
the complaint she initially made against Community Care
Organization was not applicable as they were not responsible for
case management of Youth A during the time she expected timely
social work contact.
Analysis Community Care Organization was not responsible for the case
management of Youth A during the time the potential violations
were alleged.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Visitation and family time; in person contact
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421
Section • (4) An agency shall facilitate in-person contact between
Description siblings who are not placed together except when there is a
court determination that contact is detrimental to either
child.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency failed to ensure sibling visits.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant/Foster Care Supervisor 1 – Complainant, who is
also Foster Care Supervisor 1, was interviewed via Microsoft
Teams on 1/25/2024. She reported that she misunderstood the
responsibilities of Community Care Organization staff after her
staff took over case management of Youth A’s case on 7/24/2023.
Foster Care Supervisor 2 – Foster Care Supervisor 2, who is
also the Program Manager for Community Care Organization, was
interviewed via Microsoft Teams on 1/26/2024. She reported her
staff arranged sibling visits and transported Youth A over an hour
to visits despite not having primary case management
responsibilities.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
Court orders:
• 6/21/2023 Removal order. Preliminary hearing adjourned.
Youth A’s siblings remained in the home of the mother, with
whom Youth A had a no contact order.
8

• 7/11/2023 Preliminary hearing. Sibling visits ordered to
occur 2-3 times weekly via Zoom or other electronic means
and 1 time weekly in person, or as often as can be
arranged.
Sibling Visit documentation in Youth A’s electronic case record
between 6/16/2023 and 7/24/2023.
• 7/7/2023 Foster Care Worker transported Youth A to a
sibling visit, sibling did not attend.
• 7/13/2023 Foster Care Worker 2 facilitated virtual visit
between Youth A and his sibling.
• 7/19/2023 Foster Care Worker 2 transported Youth A to
sibling visit.
There are also multiple visits documented as facilitated by
Community Care Organization after they no longer had case
management responsibility.
Analysis From the time sibling visits were ordered on 7/11/2023 until DHHS
took over case management on 7/24/2024, Community Care
organization facilitated one virtual sibling visit and one in person
sibling visit which equates to 1 virtual and one in person visit
within 8 business days.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Education/vocational training/employment
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12506
Section • (1) An agency shall ensure that it works with a youth
Description involved in independent living in the following areas as
outlined in the youth's service plan:
• (c) Education.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The agency failed to enroll the child in school.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant/Foster Care Supervisor 1 – Complainant, who is
also Foster Care Supervisor 1, was interviewed via Microsoft
Teams on 1/25/2024. She reported that she misunderstood the
responsibilities of Community Care Organization staff after her
staff took over case management of Youth A’s case on 7/24/2023.
She stated the youth would not have been in school when
9

Community Care Organization had case responsibility because it
was summer break.
Foster Care Worker 1 – Foster Care Worker 1 was interviewed
via Microsoft Teams on 1/25/2024. She stated Community Care
Organization staff stated they would enroll Youth A in school.
Foster Care Worker 1 believed they were responsible to do so,
even though she was the primary foster care worker on the case
at the time of the new school year.
Analysis Violation is not established as Community Care Organization only
had case management responsibility of Youth A during the
summer when school was not in session.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Medical, dental and mental health care
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12507
Section • (1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent
Description living receives any needed medical, dental, and mental
health care as required in R 400.12413. Medical, dental,
and mental health care provided must be documented in
the youth's record.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Medications were not documented. Youth’s mental health needs
were not addressed. Youth’s medical needs were not addressed.
ER recommendations were not followed.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Complainant/Foster Care Supervisor 1 – Complainant, who is
also Foster Care Supervisor 1, was interviewed via Microsoft
Teams on 1/25/2024. She reported that she misunderstood the
responsibilities of Community Care Organization staff after her
staff took over case management of Youth A’s case on 7/24/2023.
She initially stated Youth A did not receive follow-up treatment for
a broken arm and did not receive recommended mental health
intensive outpatient services following an emergency room visit
due to Community Care Organization not authorizing the
treatment. During the interview, she stated her concerns related to
mental health and medical services occurred when Community
Care Organization no longer had case responsibility.
Foster Care Worker 1 – Foster Care Worker 1 was interviewed
via Microsoft Teams on 1/25/2024. She stated Community Care
Organization staff did not inform her of Youth A’s injury to his hand
and she only noticed he was wearing a cast during a face-to-face
10

visit. She stated they failed to get him treatment for his hand at the
time of the injury. She reported they also did not notify her of
Youth A’s visit to the emergency room, rather a hospital social
worker called her due to Community Care Organization staff not
having proper medical care authorization, which Foster Care
Worker 1 reported they had been previously given. She stated
Youth A had gone to the emergency room after passing out and
during that visit, the doctor noticed Youth A had a hand injury
resulting from previously punching a wall. She reported
Community Care Organization did not follow-up on the
recommendations of the emergency room staff regarding
treatment for Youth A’s broken arm resulting in the bone healing
incorrectly requiring future surgery. When asked if Youth A had
informed her of his hand injury or a need for medical care during
her visits with him, she reported he did not. Foster Care 1 reported
Community Care Organization did not maintain documentation of
Youth A’s medication administration or when he refused to take
his medication. It was explained to Foster Care Worker 1 that ILP
homes are not responsible for securing, administering or
documenting medications for youths in the program and that youth
living independently are responsible to maintain their own
medication and medical treatment.
Foster Care Supervisor 2 – Foster Care Supervisor 2, who is
also the Program Manager for Community Care Organization, was
interviewed via Microsoft Teams on 1/26/2024. She stated Youth
A was brought to the emergency room after passing out while
horseplaying with another youth in the home. She reported she
was at the emergency room with Youth A at the time Foster Care
Worker 2 was contacted for authorization and notification. She
stated Youth A had been directly given the medical authorization
card (DHS 3762) by a previous worker, which he subsequently
ripped up. Foster Care Worker 2 stated she did not have a
medical authorization card for her agency and therefore could not
authorize any treatment.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
All the following documents were reviewed in Youth A’s electronic
case record:
• 6/16/2023 Consent to Routine, Non-Surgical, Medical Care,
and Emergency Medical/Surgical Treatment card (DHS-
3762) for Youth A. The caregiver section, which identified
who has the authority to consent to treatment, is left blank.
• 7/31/2023 Incident Report written by Community Care
Organization staff documenting Youth A punched a wall.
No injury or complaints of pain were documented.
11

• 8/7/2024 Case Contact written by Lenawee County DHHS
staff, Foster Care Worker 4, documenting face to face with
Youth A. No injury, complaint of pain, or request for medical
treatment were documented by Foster Care Worker 4.
• 8/7/2024 Case Contact written by Foster Care Worker 4
documenting the medical authorization card (DHS-3762)
was given directly to Youth A.
• 8/23/2023 Emergency Room discharge form documenting
Community Care Organization staff brought Youth A to the
Emergency room for a potential head injury at which time
the doctor made recommendations for follow-up care for an
injury to Youth A’s hand/arm.
Analysis At the time Youth A was brought to the emergency room on
8/28/2023, Lenawee DHHS had already taken over case
management responsibility. Foster Care Supervisor 2’s report that
her agency did not have authorization to consent to medical care
due to the authorization card being given to Youth A directly is
reflected in the case record. Follow-up medical care services
would have been the responsibility of Foster Care Worker 1 and
Youth A. Additionally, follow-up mental health services would have
to have been authorized by Foster Care Worker 1, as the
assigned foster care worker.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
February 23, 2024
______________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
February 29, 2024
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
12
